title: 105_s2348
content: The "Schools and Libraries Internet Access Act" repeals the Federal Communications Commission authority under the Communications Act of 1934 and reduces excise tax on telephone and other communication services. SEC. 3 amends the Internal Revenue Code to reduce excise tax on communication services, phasing out the tax percentage from 3.0% to 1.0%. SEC. 4 establishes the Telecommunications Technology Trust Fund. SEC. 4 establishes the Telecommunications Technology Trust Fund under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Telecommunications Technology Trust Fund is created in the Treasury, funded by taxes on communications, and available for expenditures related to the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act. The provisions of this section will end on October 1, 2003. SEC. 5. PROVISION OF TELECOMMUNICATIONS SERVICES TO SCHOOLS, LIBRARIES, AND RURAL HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS. Part A of the National Telecommunications and Information Administration Organization Act is amended to include a new section on the provision of advanced telecommunications services. The Secretary shall award grants to States for acquiring telecommunications services for health care providers in rural areas and for schools. The Secretary allocates funds to states, DC, and Puerto Rico based on population for educational services in schools and libraries. The Secretary allocates funds to states, DC, and Puerto Rico based on population for educational services in schools and libraries. States must have a State plan in effect to receive funds under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The State educational agency is designated as the responsible entity for administering the program and funds must be used solely for specified purposes. The State plan must allocate funds for acquiring telecommunications services and administration, with a limit of 2 percent for administrative costs. Criteria for fund distribution should consider economic need, especially in areas with high concentrations of low-income families. The State plan must allocate funds for acquiring telecommunications services and administration, with a limit of 2 percent for administrative costs. Funds should be distributed based on economic need, particularly in areas with high concentrations of low-income families living in sparsely populated areas. Funds must be spent according to regulations set by the Secretary. Telecommunications services provided to schools, libraries, and healthcare providers cannot be sold or transferred for money or any other value. The Secretary has the authority to create regulations for this program. The Secretary's designee will establish regulations for qualifications and conditions to carry out provisions for acquiring telecommunications services for schools and libraries. Criteria will determine if equipment installation is essential for access to advanced technologies. The term 'health care provider' includes post-secondary educational institutions, teaching hospitals, community health centers, local health departments, mental health centers, hospitals, and rural health clinics. Entities eligible for grants under this section must operate as not-for-profit businesses and not be schools with endowments over $50,000,000 or libraries ineligible for assistance under the Library Services and Technology Act. Expenditure Authority: Appropriations can be made from the Telecommunications Technology Trust Fund for grants and program administration for fiscal years 1999 through 2003. The Telecommunications Technology Trust Fund appropriations for grants in fiscal year 1999 are limited to $1,700,000,000. Any unexpended balances can be transferred to the general fund of the Treasury. For fiscal year 2004 and beyond, up to $500,000,000 can be appropriated from Treasury funds for grants and program administration. The amendments made by sections 2 and 5 of this Act will take effect 180 days after enactment, while the amendments made by sections 3 and 4 will be effective immediately upon enactment.
